title: Making Space for Development - developing high level skills for business growth in SMEs
abstractText:
The original Evolution of Business Knowledge grant (RES-334-25-0015) focused on developing an understanding of how owner managers dealt with ‘critical incidents’ that concerned their businesses an inhibited their growth.  The findings highlighted two important distinguishing factors that related to sources of innovation. One related to human capital the other, absorptive capacity. The findings have significant implications for SME managers which this impact grant seeks to address.
The main focus of the dissemination is aimed at intermediaries, universities, further education colleges and private sector providers in the North of England specialising in enterprise. By becoming more aware of the findings of our research we aim to help them to embed in practice the various ways they can help managers create ‘strategic space’. This awareness raising will extend to pedagogical elements of education programmes that will enable providers to better connect with the smaller firm. To undertake the main elements of the grant, we aim to connect to key members of each of the communities identified above; produce a number of tools to be used by management developers and intermediaries and based on our research, to stimulate thought and discussion with the aim of raising performance. We will also produce a number of case studies of good practice more generally.
impactText: The findings of the research have been used to give partner institutions within the Northern Leadership Academy Network materials based on the findings of the Evolution of Business Knowledge in SMEs project (RES-334-25-0015) Education Societal,Economic,Policy & public services
findingsText: We have distributed 'principles' of good practice related to knowledge acquisition and the development of small and medium sized enterprises. These should be extremely useful to providers who are aiming to help small firms and their managers grow and develop. Our findings have been incorporated into a practitioner book that should be taken to assist in SME development and growth and the development of managers. The findings build on and confirm the understandings that have been developed within the field of Small Business Education and Development. Government, Democracy and Justice
